resources.string: Measure allows you to obtain a variety of magnitudes in just a few clicks. Try it out!

The app Measure is the result of a TdR (Treball de Recerca), a project in which students get the opportunity to research in a specific field they like.
The aim of the project is to give everyone a reliable tool to measure and identify the geometries around them at any situation, without any necessity of specific equipment which is not usually carried around, like a meter. To archive that, the solution uses something we all have with us everywhere, our mobile phones. Although there are some solutions which use a more sophisticated way of doing it, we wanted to explore a more mathematical approach. 
This project was developed between 2018 and 2019 by the student Albert Canales Ros, and tutored by Jordi Sorolla, PhD in Mathematics. 
The whole process of making the app can be found on GitHub by clicking the button below. 
In order to contact us for any reason, we would appreciate you to do it by the email: albertcanalesros@gmail.com. 
We hope you enjoy the app and you find it useful!
Can you take the measurements from a known height?

With measure, you can easily calculate distances, angles, areas and volumes around you. To do so, you will simply have to aim at the points which form them using the camera and following the steps on the next slides. Once you have obtained all the necessary points you can get the desired magnitudes.
Swipe to learn how to use the app!
Firstly, let\'s consider how to position the device during the measurement.

As you have given your height on the previous activity, stand still during the measurement and locate the device at the height of your chest. \nIt is recommended to give a specific height if known, in order to get more precise results.
As you have selected \'Of course\' and entered a specific height on the previous slide, you will have to locate the device at the given height from the ground.

Before starting the measure of the points, locate yourself and the device on a comfortable position, where you can see the screen and aim at the points correctly. To aim at the points, you can only rotate the device keeping its camera steady, as moving it from its initial position will highly worsen the results.

Before considering how to measure points, some simple concepts have to be explained. To be able to measure any point in space, you will firstly need to measure its \'Base Point. That is to say, a point in the same place but on the ground. A comparison can be seen on the picture.
Note that if the desired point is on the ground, no previous point measurement is necessary.

To measure a point, click the \'Add\' button on the top-right corner and select an option the according type regarding if the desired point is on the ground (Based Point) or not (Non-based point). To mark a point, click the button-middle button. Remember that if the desired point is not on the ground, you will have to aim first at its \'Base Point\' (explained in the previous slide). You can cancel a point measurement by clicking on the bottom-left corner button. You can finish measuring points and get to the results by clicking on the bottom-right corner button.
To obtain precise values, measure the points following these steps:
Pan the camera around in order to aim at the same direction of the desired point.
Rotate the camera on a nodding movement to aim at the point.
Wait a second for the sensors to stabilise and mark the point.
